review_title: My department's pretty awesome, so I've been pleased
pros: -Working from home full time. -Great variety of voluntary benefits (AFLAC is AWESOME! I purchased the indemnity and STD coverage and it has come in handy) -different pay grades pay different benefit prices, which is nice for those of us who aren't higher up. -EAP has been helpful - pension plan and 401K is decent. - if you have a disability, work partners helps protect your job and are very underatanding. Management in my dept has always been very empathetic to my disability and needs -my health at work. Super great, no copay for sick visit at work if you have an office. - cheap copay for virtual sick care as well - Leslie Davis seems to be doing a lot more than Jeff Romoff ever did. - lots of advancement within company once you get your foot in the door. - they added an HRA for employees at no cost to help cover out of pocket costs and it rolls over! It's been very helpful. - doing TAHS makes your deductible go down. It's as easy as yearly exams you get anyhow, plus a few extras.
cons: -The health insurance has gone up a lot. The copays are rough, especially the ER copay. - the pay... You get a review yearly and it's always under 50 cents. Leslie Davis did give us non clinical employees a bonus (it was taxed which sucks) but they will sometimes adjust your pay due to national average, but I got a few pennies. Kind of a slap in the face. Hasn't alleviated any inflation. - work partners is great but they are short staffed a lot and people take a long time to answer questions. - talking to IT does nothing. It takes forever to get help, if at all. I think they have a high turnover rate. - we had great vision one year, but they claimed people complained about it being "too generous" and they got rid of it. What the heck?

pros:
Great supervisors and upper management. Overall good company morale. Great benefits, especially if you live in Pittsburgh, your health insurance will go a long way since the company is based in Pitt.
Great work life balance as well. I’ve never heard the word No from management when I need assistance. It’s a great environment if this is what you are passionate about doing.
cons:
Awful pay, found out that someone with zero experience coming into the company, is making almost 2xs what I and other coworkers are making. I don’t want to sound bitter but I mean… if someone with 3-4 years of experience is making less than 50K a year but someone with 0 years of experience is making 60K+… it doesn’t sit right with me. If you pay me less than 50K a year then that is the quality of work you will receive. 
Another con would be they lie about what your caseload will be… in the interview they said 65 people on a caseload but really you’re pushing 85+ people on your caseload.

review_title: Moved to greener pastures, Sad direction for healthcare
pros: Its certainly a job, if you need one. Lots of interaction with other employees, access to some powerful software. Some parts of PA look nice if you can get a window with a view, annual travel opportunities.
cons: Large majority of local and corporate managers/directors, etc are simply those who have stuck around since the 80's & 90's, not leaders who were the best/most capable candidates of any competitive hiring processes within the past couple decades. Suboptimal management styles, lack of proper leadership & business educations, and reliance on misguided/personal preference philosophies are glaring. You could say to your supervisor "Hey Jim there is literally an adult alligator in the bathroom." and Jim will literally say "Well back in the 80s we didn't have alligators, or bathrooms! So just ignore your life outside of work and you'll do great." Corporation is expanding but not growing the existing teams who support the increasing workloads, underappreciative of essential employees in food/cleaning/support roles who provide for everyone else in the enterprise. Leadership spends years starting to think about maybe making improvements to the biggest challenges and issues for the enterprise on things they should have planned for 10 years ago, then hire outside consultants rather than use the complaints & suggestions of thousands of knowledgeable current employees to gain any insight... Both old and new CEOs just want to get their picture next to as many news articles as possible, no matter how superficial the content is, almost all of which they had no involvement in/knowledge of until someone whose fulltime job is to write one half-page, large print, magazine article per month has finished the article. Real-estate and building space management teams literally give themselves multiple renovated private offices and stack other teams in literal walk-in closets. Corporate leadership teams weirdly single out and groom certain female interns for special treatment and creation of new pre-selected, laid-back corporate positions. Administrative leaders unconsciously show off their (paid-for by non-profit) unethically luxurious home offices while remotely showing up for Mon-Weds meetings (they don't work often Thursdays and Fridays) Majority of capable employees have no trust or confidence in leadership, but will say they do when the company asks of course, in fear of their job security. Company throws away mega millions in working modern equipment annually, and keeps what they should throw away when it comes to software and policies/practices. Due to overworked/ poor choices in central IT design, the company wastes many dozens of millions annually on paid time doctors are sitting in front of patients waiting for the computers to load up, many of my doctors know and complain about this. Company could hire a couple capable software engineers to build replacements of much software for 1/100th of the annual software license/rental costs.

pros: Work from home, decent and affordable benefits
cons: Just don’t. Don’t apply here, don’t accept a position here, it will suck the soul out of you. Across the board whether you are in a corporate setting or hospital staff, the entire company is severely understaffed and underpaid (even before Covid). UPMC would rather pocket it’s profits to further monopolize the job industry in PA (as the largest employer) and continue to build new fancy structures and take over more hospital chains instead of paying their employees decent wages. They expect you to meet all goals and compliancy whenever it realistically would take 2-3 people to maintain their expectations (but they want 1 person to cover it). Get used to working 70-80 hours a week with no overtime pay and no worries worklife balance and poor sleep and mental health. I watched several coworkers over the years take medical leaves because their mental health suffered so badly working here. Massive turnover, a revolving door of new employees being hired with little knowledge and veteraned staff leaving out of frustration. Terrible training, thrown to the wolves, acquiring caseloads already several months behind right out of the gate. You are set up for failure. Micromanaged. And yet even though you feel like a slave or a robot you still barely make enough money to get your bills paid. Absolutely do not do it if you care about having a life to live and maintaining your mental health.

review_title: Mixed culture depending on business unit/leadership
pros:
-Strong mission statement and values focusing on diversity and inclusion
-Invests heavily in mentorship, provides ample learning and professional growth opportunities, and facilitates collaboration across diverse departments/divisions
-Flexible work arrangements for most of IT division (primarily remote/work from home positions, but with optional hoteling space available)
-Good healthcare and other benefits, generous paid time off program
-Relatively long-term job security
cons:
-Team culture, work-life balance, and employee satisfaction vary depending on which department and management/leadership you work for
-Inadequate base salaries and unwilling to reward long-term employees, sometimes offering higher salaries to new hires (often with less experience)
-Ambiguous job titles lack clear differentiation and have overlapping pay scales (management can make less than their direct reports)
-Seemingly non-existent standards for promotion, leading to inequities within and across departments and divisions
-Convoluted performance/merit reward system, forcing management to often award the same or only slightly higher % increase to mid-level performers as those going above and beyond. Most recent cap for annual raises barely covers the cost of living
-Lack of clear direction from business and IT leadership, little to no prioritization of strategic projects, constant barrage of new requests/mandatory changes causing constant burn-out

pros:
PTO - around 23 days accrued over a year with ability to roll over a lot of it
Low cost health insurance
Work from home flexibility...if you're on a certain Team. (Not all HR leaders allow WFH)
Exposed to a ton that will build up your resume to prepare you to eventually leave
Lots of internal resources like Legal, Compliance, and HR partners to go to to ensure you're doing everything correctly. 
You have a part in the overall mission by bringing in talent to the organization to take care of the patients.
On-site employee health clinics.
Career ladder within TA and HR roles (HR makes more and you will have to beg for a promotion a year in advanced, have it dangled in your face, jump through hoops, then be told it was not approved due to budget.
cons:
Very low pay. 
Work/Life balance - many of us working over 40hrs per week
Extremely high expectations from internal leaders who have no understanding of TA
TA was decentralized in 2020 and now reports directly into HR teams who have no idea what TA does. You also make less than the HR consultants while being expected to help out with their Employee Relations work
Lots of pressure to fill jobs but there is no retention plans in place by HR teams for those you hire. 
TA is blamed for the inability to fill positions despite the fact that UPMC pays people extremely low and retention in the departments is very poor. 
Leader within the organization are mediocre or poor leaders. Should not be in leadership Roles.
TA is very unappreciated and understaffed. Revolving door... 
Req loads are very disproportioned amongst Recruiters. 
Culture sucks now that TA is decentralized.
Very shady internal promotions. They reward mediocracy.

review_title: Faux commitment to excellence; abysmal regard for employee safety
pros: -Some fellow associates mean well and are good to work with
cons:
-Leadership and HR not committed to enforcing safety policies in COVID season (leaders do not always wear masks at the office, inconsistent policies on virtual work in the corporate space during the COVID pandemic)
-Executive leadership stays in a bubble - not truly accessible to the average employee experience
-Pay is at the low end of the spectrum
-Leadership says they are committed to excellence and innovation, as long as you tell them what they want to hear and do things the way they always have been done
-Inconsistent treatment of health in employees: for example, they offer PTO days for donating blood and no alternatives for associates who are ineligible due to their health status
-Policies and procedures create an atmosphere of perpetual man-made emergencies and fire drills for issues that are not not worth it
